title: Synthetic Recap
body:
NEW YORK — In the hallowed halls of Madison Square Garden, where legends are forged, Bernard King authored one final, unforgettable masterpiece for the New York Knicks. On a night that transcended a mere regular-season contest, King turned back the clock, delivering a performance for the ages and carrying his team to a thrilling 107-103 victory over the Minnesota Timberwolves.

From the opening tip, it was clear something special was brewing. King, the veteran scorer with a warrior’s heart, was unstoppable. He sliced through the lane, hit from mid-range, and drew fouls with a relentless aggression that the Timberwolves had no answer for. By halftime, he had already piled up a staggering point total, a portent of the history to come.

As the game tightened in the second half, every possession ran through King. The Garden crowd, sensing they were witnessing greatness, rose to its feet with every touch. Minnesota, led by a valiant 25-point effort from Tom Gugliotta, refused to yield, but King met every challenge. With the game on the line in the final minutes, he coolly sank free throws, each one punctuating his legendary night.

When the final horn sounded, the scoreboard told the tale of a narrow Knicks win, but the stat sheet told a far grander story: Bernard King had poured in 45 points. In a virtuoso display of scoring artistry, he had not only willed his team to victory but had also etched his name once more into the franchise’s lore, a timeless performance in the world’s most famous arena.
